commit_message:
Use monotonic lib. to avoid finding monotonic time function

That library already does this same/equivalent search and
ensures that a monotonically increasing time is made available
so we can just avoid looking around for it ourselves.

Change-Id: I2b5c69430d75a095f6743c10e2d9281f7d9120e0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/81/190381/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: def find_monotonic(allow_time_time=False): """Tries to find a monotonic time providing function (and returns it).""" for import_str in _MONOTONIC_LOCATIONS: mod_str, _sep, attr_str = import_str.rpartition('.') mod = importutils.try_import(mod_str) if mod is None: continue func = getattr(mod, attr_str, None) if func is not None: return func # Finally give up and use time.time (which isn't monotonic)... if allow_time_time: return time.time else: return None

commit_message:
Port Event based Subnet binding and ARP responder install

Change the Subnet binding and ARP responder to be dynamically (only
where needed) installed as response to port status form the switch ,
Until this patch we looped on all the subnets and routers on all port
status ignoring the actual port configured on the switch

Change-Id: I59d03ffc52a9b47eeebe4f467a1d41fe1844c8ae

commit_message:
Drop use of 'oslo' namespace package

The Oslo libraries have moved all of their code out of the 'oslo'
namespace package into per-library packages. The namespace package was
retained during kilo for backwards compatibility, but will be removed by
the liberty-2 milestone. This change removes the use of the namespace
package, replacing it with the new package names.

The patches in the libraries will be put on hold until application
patches have landed, or L2, whichever comes first. At that point, new
versions of the libraries without namespace packages will be released as
a major version update.

Please merge this patch, or an equivalent, before L2 to avoid problems
with those library releases.

Blueprint: remove-namespace-packages
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo-incubator/+spec/remove-namespace-packages

Change-Id: I797d23fc5283e1951f8f75eecc23830b1ae0de69

commit_message:
Implement external physical bridge mapping in linuxbridge

In some deployment scenario, it is not allowed to remove system
ethernet configuration from physical interface to newly-created
physical bridge by neutron due to some IT regulations.

End-users require to take advantage of the pre-existed(user-defined)
physical bridge to connect tap devices.

Change-Id: Ic76907a852f8e85d47fdc4286cf86ac57076ce34
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/83/173683/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================================================= Support external physical bridge mapping in linuxbridge ======================================================= Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/phy-net-bridge-mapping This proposal implements physical bridge mapping for linuxbridge-agent. According to this proposal, linuxbridge-agent will be able to be aware of external user-defined physical bridges and attach tap devices on it. Problem Description =================== The linuxbridge-agent currently creates a bridge for each physical network used as a flat network, moving any existing IP address from the interface to the newly created bridge. This is very helpful in some cases, but there are other cases where the ability to use a pre-existing (user-defined) bridge. For instance, the same physical network might need to be bridged for other purposes, or the agent moving the system's IP might not be desired or cause some unexpected error for the pre-defined environment. According to some enterprise end-users' feedbacks, they do need this feature to make neutron compatible with their pre-defined virtual network environment due to some security regulations. Proposed Change =============== Add a physical_bridge_mappings configuration variable, similar to that used by the openvswitch-agent, alongside the current physical_interface_mappings variable. When a physical bridge for a flat network is needed, the bridge mappings would be checked first. If a bridge mapping for the physical network exists, it would be used. If not, the interface mapping would be used and a bridge for the interface would be created automatically. Sub-interfaces and bridges for VLAN networks would continue to work as they do now, created by the agent using the interface mappings. Data Model Impact ----------------- None. REST API Impact --------------- None. Security Impact --------------- None. Notifications Impact -------------------- None. Other End User Impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. IPv6 Impact ----------- None. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Add an option called physical_bridge_mappings in /etc/neutron/plugins/linuxbridge/linuxbridge_conf.ini. Developer Impact ---------------- None. Community Impact ---------------- This change is a value-added feature for linuxbridge-agent, and it won't affect the current development cycle. The implementation is simple and straightforward. Alternatives ------------ None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: nick-ma-z Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Implement the feature * Provide unit tests Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- None. Functional Tests ---------------- None. This new feature can be fully covered by unit test cases. API Tests --------- None. Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ Add an option called physical_bridge_mappings in /etc/neutron/plugins/linuxbridge/linuxbridge_conf.ini. Developer Documentation ----------------------- None. References ========== See related bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1105488

commit_message:
DO NOT MERGE: Example of using VIF plug script

This patch is a sample usage of the proposed VIF_PLUGIN_SCRIPT
mechanism. This field will be populated by a Neutron mechanism driver
and refers to driver specific script that will be called from the
virtualization driver when the system is ready to connect the guest to a
L2 network.

Change-Id: I3b5daadc9bba446cd6c644f1052b05cb77111b19
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/71/162471/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Make l3 agent prefix delegation pluggable

Unlocks the prefix delegation feature so that developers may create
drivers for other prefix delegation services in the future.
Operators can select the driver via the new configuration option
"pd_dhcp_driver".

DocImpact
Change-Id: I2a9342c14825458f814d1ec9fa5a992b7f6e13f7
Implements: blueprint ipv6-prefix-delegation

added_lines: import importlibfrom oslo_config import cfg OPTS = [ cfg.StrOpt('pd_dhcp_driver', default='neutron.agent.linux.dibbler', help=_('Service to handle DHCPv6 Prefix delegation')), ] cfg.CONF.register_opts(OPTS) pd_driver = importlib.import_module(cfg.CONF.pd_dhcp_driver) self.pd_dhcp_driver = pd_driver pdo['pdobject'] = self.pd_dhcp_driver.PDManager( router_id, subnet_id, pdo['ri_ifname']) sync_data = self.pd_dhcp_driver.get_sync_data()
deleted_lines: from neutron.agent.linux import dibbler pdo['pdobject'] = dibbler.PDDibbler(router_id, subnet_id, pdo['ri_ifname']) sync_data = dibbler.get_sync_data()

In order to use prefix delegation without the use of an external service
such as Dibbler this patch adds a small agent dedicated to handling
DHCPv6 Prefix Delegation which can run alongside the L3 Agent.

The API for PD drivers in the L3 Agent is slightly changed to make it
as pluggable as possible.

This patch adds several new configuration options which firstly allow the
Prefix Delegation driver to be set in the config file along with the
ability to customise some parts of the DHCPv6 conversation.

The agent can be started using the "neutron-dhcpv6-client" command and
must run with elevated privileges.

The L3 Agent communicates with this service via Unix sockets, using the
PDManager we implement.

Co-Authored-By: Bradley Jones <jones.bradley@me.com>

Change-Id: Ic3849b4f0ad64804b642d00daadb9f265f2a7b62

commit_message:
Add an internal DHCPv6 agent for Prefix Delegation

In order to use prefix delegation without the use of an external service
such as Dibbler this patch adds a small agent dedicated to handling
DHCPv6 Prefix Delegation which can run alongside the L3 Agent.

The agent can be started using the "neutron-pd-agent" command and
must run with elevated privileges. The L3 Agent communicates with this
service via a driver which can be enabled in the neutron settings file
by setting pd_dhcp_driver to neutron_pd_agent.

In order to configure the neutron PD agent the "pd_socket_loc" and
"pd_interface" configuration options have been added.

Co-Authored-By: Bradley Jones <jones.bradley@me.com>

DocImpact
Change-Id: Ic3849b4f0ad64804b642d00daadb9f265f2a7b62
Implements: blueprint neutron-ipv6-prefix-delegation-service
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/81/161381/17 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.agent.linux import dhcpv6client dhcpv6client.disable_ipv6_pd(self.pmon, router_id, subnet_id, dhcpv6client.disable_ipv6_pd(self.pmon, router_id, subnet_id, prefix = dhcpv6client.get_prefix(router_id, subnet_id, dhcpv6client.enable_ipv6_pd(self.pmon, self.pd_update_cb, sync_data = dhcpv6client.get_sync_data()
deleted_lines: from neutron.agent.linux import dibbler dibbler.disable_ipv6_pd(self.pmon, router_id, subnet_id, dibbler.disable_ipv6_pd(self.pmon, router_id, subnet_id, prefix = dibbler.get_prefix(router_id, subnet_id, dibbler.enable_ipv6_pd(self.pmon, sync_data = dibbler.get_sync_data()

subject: Return early from RPC call handlers with no return value
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-12 20:54:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/05f8ab3568004b2d31883b6cff790128355fc40b', 'message': "Return early from RPC call handlers with no return value

Oslo messaging reminder:
cast: Send and forget. You only get an ACK from the messaging server,
not from the intended recipient.
call: Block until the recipient sends a return value or exception.

Agents often use call and not cast when updating about certain events,
even though the recipient (Neutron server in this case) has no return
value on the RPC endpoint (Think OVS agent update_device_up). The intention
is to notify that something happened, so naturally you don't care about
a return value. In the cases I observed there is no error handling in
the agents either.

Since there's no need to wait for a response or to see if the server
successfully updates whatever it is that it needs to update, we have
two choices:
a) Switch from call to cast in these cases
b) It can still be preferable to use call and not cast to get a
   stronger delivery guarantee. Perhaps you'd still want to bug out
   if the recipient is down or otherwise non-responsive.

Note: The oslo.notify API uses call underneath so that's not a real
      alternative.

In this patch I propose B, because honestly it's easier for my puny
mind to imagine a world where when one side sends a message the other
side actually receives it, and not operate under an assumption where
notifications are non-reliable. Keeping that in mind, I prefer call to cast.
If this is way off base please do call me out!

To remedy the performance hit, I changed the RPC endpoints on the server
to process the message with eventlet.spawn_n, following a conversation
with sileht from Oslo messaging (This pattern is common in Nova).

Surprisingly, from my very simple tests with ml2.report_device_up,
this did not make a big difference from the agent's point of view.
It seems like most of the time in a call is spent in
Oslo messaging overhead or rabbit, but not processing the response on
the server. Still, this change could make an impact on other RPC messages
or at scale. It will also let us leverage ongoing performance work in
Oslo messaging such as:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+bug/1437951

Change-Id: I012dfb709622b2a48705d6a999856c7ae93a7ca2
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-05-12 21:08:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/abf2fd631ffbf35fbb90af9808eaa4ef54468407', 'message': "Return early from RPC call handlers with no return value

WIP: I pushed this to get early feedback and start a discussion.
I still need to observe each occurrence and make sure it doesn't
screw up something.

Oslo messaging reminder:
cast: Send and forget. You only get an ACK from the messaging server,
not from the intended recipient.
call: Block until the recipient sends a return value or exception.

Agents often use call and not cast when updating about certain events,
even though the recipient (Neutron server in this case) has no return
value on the RPC endpoint (Think OVS agent update_device_up). The intention
is to notify that something happened, so naturally you don't care about
a return value. In the cases I observed there is no error handling in
the agents either.

Since there's no need to wait for a response or to see if the server
successfully updates whatever it is that it needs to update, we have
two choices:
a) Switch from call to cast in these cases
b) It can still be preferable to use call and not cast to get a
   stronger delivery guarantee. Perhaps you'd still want to bug out
   if the recipient is down or otherwise non-responsive.

Note: The oslo.notify API uses call underneath so that's not a real
      alternative.

In this patch I propose B, because honestly it's easier for my puny
mind to imagine a world where when one side sends a message the other
side actually receives it, and not operate under an assumption where
notifications are non-reliable. Keeping that in mind, I prefer call to cast.
If this is way off base please do call me out!

To remedy the performance hit, I changed the RPC endpoints on the server
to process the message with eventlet.spawn_n, following a conversation
with sileht from Oslo messaging (This pattern is common in Nova).

Surprisingly, from my very simple tests with ml2.report_device_up,
this did not make a big difference from the agent's point of view.
It seems like most of the time in a call is spent in
Oslo messaging overhead or rabbit, but not processing the response on
the server. Still, this change could make an impact on other RPC messages
or when the neutron server is busy. It will also let us leverage ongoing
performance work in Oslo messaging such as:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+bug/1437951

Change-Id: I012dfb709622b2a48705d6a999856c7ae93a7ca2

commit_message:
Return early from RPC call handlers with no return value

Oslo messaging reminder:
cast: Send and forget. You only get an ACK from the messaging server,
not from the intended recipient.
call: Block until the recipient sends a return value or exception.

Agents often use call and not cast when updating about certain events,
even though the recipient (Neutron server in this case) has no return
value on the RPC endpoint (Think OVS agent update_device_up). The intention
is to notify that something happened, so naturally you don't care about
a return value. In the cases I observed there is no error handling in
the agents either.

Since there's no need to wait for a response or to see if the server
successfully updates whatever it is that it needs to update, we have
two choices:
a) Switch from call to cast in these cases
b) It can still be preferable to use call and not cast to get a
   stronger delivery guarantee. Perhaps you'd still want to bug out
   if the recipient is down or otherwise non-responsive.

Note: The oslo.notify API uses cast underneath so that's not a real
      alternative.

In this patch I propose B, because honestly it's easier for my puny
mind to imagine a world where when one side sends a message the other
side actually receives it, and not operate under an assumption where
notifications are non-reliable. Keeping that in mind, I prefer call to cast.
If this is way off base please do call me out!

To remedy the performance hit, I changed the RPC endpoints on the server
to process the message with eventlet.spawn_n, following a conversation
with sileht from Oslo messaging (This pattern is common in Nova).

Surprisingly, from my very simple tests with ml2.report_device_up,
this did not make a big difference from the agent's point of view.
It seems like most of the time in a call is spent in
Oslo messaging overhead or rabbit, but not processing the response on
the server. Still, this change could make an impact on other RPC messages
or when the neutron server is busy. It will also let us leverage ongoing
performance work in Oslo messaging such as:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+bug/1437951

Change-Id: I012dfb709622b2a48705d6a999856c7ae93a7ca2

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import functools import eventlet def return_early(f): @functools.wraps(f) def use_spawn_n(*args, **kwargs): eventlet.spawn_n(f, *args, **kwargs) return use_spawn_n

commit_message:
Implements : Blueprint user-centric-naas

Change-Id: I38dd89cd6f908d10a41a106a9e4e60d02ba4f104
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/07/169207/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================================ User-Centric NaaS ============================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/user-centric-naas User-Centric NaaS API is for NaaS users/subscribers to describe their E2E (End-to-End) networking service requirements among user endpoints. User endpoints may be DC gateway, branch office gateway, enterprise gateway, home gateway, server, VM, laptops, desktops, phones. NaaS users/subscribers mainly care about their E2E networking service requirements in the form of service contracts, including SLA (Service Level Agreement), bandwidth profile, time schedule and fine-grained value-added service parameters. These E2E networking service requirements are platform-agnostic and should be automatically compiled and mapped into underlying platform-specific network control or configuration APIs by the User-Centric NaaS Engine with conflicts checking and resolution. With the User-Centric NaaS API, NaaS users/subscribers can easily describe their E2E NaaS service instances. A service instance specifies which service_type and service_contract can be accessed by a UEP or a list of UEPs with the same NaaS service requirements to communicate with other UEPs. A tenant ID is used to identify a NaaS user/subscriber. A tenant may have multiple service graphs. With the same service_name string, multiple service instances are associated into a P2Net (Point-to-external-Network), P2P (Point-to-Point), MP2MP (MultiPoint-to-MultiPoint), or RMP (Rooted-MultiPoint) basic service. With the same service_graph_id value, multiple basic services are associated into a service graph in a hybrid way. Problem Description =================== Currently Neutron provides the APIs of virtual network resource abstraction, such as Network, Subnet, Port, Bridge, Router, etc. People familiar with networking technology can use these APIs to describe their virtual network resource requirements. But for those people not familiar with networking technology or only care about the E2E networking service requirements, they do not want the virtual network resources details. Moreover, they want their E2E networking service requirements can be automatically compiled and mapped into underlying control or configuration API of virtual or physical network resources. User-Centric NaaS API is designed to satisfy these requirements with the following features: 1. Should be centered on the user endpoints and their E2E networking service requirements, including service schedule, SLA parameters, bandwidth profile, and fine-grained value-added service. 2. Should support user endpoints having multiple addresses in a multilayer network. 3. Should support various connectivity and isolation requirements among user endpoints, such as P2Net, P2P, MP2MP, RMP. 4. Should support the service requirements of multiple user endpoints in a service may be different or same. 5. Should support the ingress and egress service requirements of a user endpoint may be different or same. 6. Should support a tenant may have multiple service graphs for different service domains. 7. Should support a service graph may contain multiple P2Net, P2P, MP2MP, RMP basic services. 8. Should support value-added service may be dynamically activated by events, such as alarms from User-Experience Monitoring API when committed SLA parameters are not satisfied. 9. Should be automatically compiled and mapped into underlying control or configuration APIs of virtual or physical network resources. Proposed Change =============== This blueprint proposes User-Centric NaaS API and User-Experience Monitoring API(item 1-2) and their compiling and mapping into underlying control or configuration APIs (item 3): 1. User-Centric NaaS API to address the description of E2E User-Centric networking requirements. 2. User-Experience monitoring API to address the description of E2E User-Experience Monitoring requirements. 3. A framework of User-Centric NaaS Engine for their compiling and mapping into underlying control or configuration API of virtual or physical network resources with conflicts checking and resolution. More specifically, the User-Centric NaaS API and User-Experience Monitoring API and their corresponding data models will be illustrated in the following parts of this blueprint. A new terminology is introduced in this blueprint. * UEP (user endpoint): The user device connects directly to a network, which is physical or virtual and may have one or multiple unique addresses in the network. UEP may be DC gateway, branch office gateway, enterprise gateway, home gateway, server, VM, laptops, desktops, phones. The identifier of a UEP is a UUID for orchestrator & controller to identify a set of one or more network endpoints reachable via an external interface on the service provider's network. For human-friendly, the name of a UEP is the device name string. Besides UEP, the following terminologies are used by the data models in this blueprint: * UEP_service_role: This is used for the UEP service role in the service type including Root and Leaf. In a RMP (i.e. P2MP) service, root UEPs can communicate with each other, root UEPs can communicate with leaf UEPs, but leaf UEPs cannot communicate with each other. In a P2Net/P2P/MP2MP service, UEP_service_role of all UEPs are root or could be omitted. * UEP_traffic_role: This is used for the UEP role in the traffic direction including Generator (one-way data source), Consumer (one-way data sink) and Participant (two-way symmetric data source/sink). If the egress and ingress service requirements of a UEP are different, then we use two service_contracts for the egress and ingress of a UEP separately. Otherwise, we can use only one service_contract for the bidirectional of a UEP concisely. * Composite_UEP_address: This is used as the container of a list of UEP_addresses for a UEP which has multiple addresses in a multilayer network. In some use cases a UEP may have only one UEP_address, while in other use cases a UEP may have a list of UEP_addresses. E.g. if a UEP is a VM, it has an IP address and a MAC address. If a UEP is a gateway of a LAN, it has an IP subnet prefix and multiple MAC addresses representing all endpoints in the LAN. * UEP_address: This is used for the address information of UEP, which has been registered for use in the network. The address information of UEP should be enough for orchestrator & controller to address a UEP and identify its service traffic at UNI for the connectivity. UEP address information may be a street address, device serial number, MAC address, VLAN ID, IP address, etc. * Service_graph_ID: This is used to associate multiple basic services in order to achieve a whole service graph. A tenant may have multiple service graphs. With the same service_graph_id value, multiple P2Net/P2P/MP2MP/RMP basic services are associated into a service graph in a hybrid way. * Service_name: This is used to associate multiple service instances in order to achieve a whole P2Net, P2P, MP2MP or RMP basic service. A basic service may have multiple UEPs, and so may have multiple service instances if these UEPs egress, ingress or bidirectional NaaS service requirements are different. With the same service_name string, multiple service instances are associated into a P2Net/P2P/MP2MP/RMP basic service. * Service_type: This is used for the NaaS service type of a basic service including P2Net (Point to Internet), P2P (Point to Point), MP2MP (Multipoint to Multipoint) or RMP (Rooted Multipoint), which indicates the connectivity and isolation requirement. * User-Centric NaaS service instance: This is used for specifying in a User-Centric NaaS service instance which service_type and service_contract can be accessed by a UEP or a list of UEPs with the same NaaS service requirements to communicate with other UEPs. A list of UEPs, which have the same NaaS service requirements, can be associated to the same service_contract. E.g. a List of UEPs in a LAN may have same P2Net NaaS service requirements. A list of UEPs at all sites of a VPN may have same MP2MP NaaS service requirements. * Service_contract: This is used for the aggregation of the NaaS service requirements including servicel_level, service_schedule, bandwidth_profile, leased_type and value_added_service. * Leased_type: This is used for the committed leased type, namely service layer, which indicates the service frame (or packet) definition used for bandwidth profiles. * Service_level: This is used for describing the SLA requirement including availability, delay, delay_variation, and loss_ratio. * Service_schedule: This is used for describing the service life cycle requirement including start_time, start_interval, period, duration. * Bandwidth_profile: This is used for the committed bandwidth requirement. * Event: This is used for describing the events that triggers the associated actions, such as delay_alarm, delay_variation_alarm, loss_ratio _alarm, load_ratio_alarm and timer. * Classifier: This is used for describing the traffic classifiers for the associated actions, such as user_id, flow_id, URL or app_type. * Action: This is used for describing the particular traffic handling triggered by the associated events on the traffic characterized by the associated classifiers. * Value_added_service: This is used for the association of events, classifiers and actions for describing the value-added service requirement. * User-Experience Monitoring instance: This is used for specifying a E2E User-Experience Monitoring instance between two user endpoints. * Experience: This is used for describing the types of User-Experience, such as reachability, load ratio, delay, delay variation, loss ratio of IP, TCP, UDP, HTTP. The relationship of the proposed terms and objects is illustrated in the following figure. +---------------------+ | | +--------+ User-Centric NaaS +--------+ | | service instance | | | | | | | +---------------------+ | +---+--+ | | UEP | +-------+--------+ +---+--+ |Service_contract| | +-------+--------+ +-----+-----+ +------------+-----------+--------------+ | Composite_| | | | | |UEP_address| +---+---+ +----+---+ +----+----+ +------+----+ +-----+-----+ |Service| |Service_| |Bandwidth| |Value_added| | |_level | |schedule| |_profile | | _service | +-----+-----+ +-------+ +--------+ +---------+ +------+----+ |UEP_address| | +-----------+ +----------+-----------+ | | | +--+--+ +----+-----+ +--+---+ |Event| |Classifier| |Action| +-----+ +----------+ +------+ The User-Centric NaaS service requirements are described in a hierarchical way. The following figure shows one of a tenant's complex service graph which consist of the following five basic services, MP2MP_abc, MP2MP_defg, P2P_cd, RMP_bhij, and P2Net_g. Illustrations: 1. UEP_a:participant, UEP_b:participant and UEP_c:participant can communicate with each other through a basic MP2MP service with the service_name 'MP2MP_abc'. 2. UEP_d:participant, UEP_e:participant, UEP_f:participant and UEP_g:participant can communicate with each other through a basic MP2MP service with the service_name 'MP2MP_defg'. 3. UEP_c:participant and UEP_d:participant can communicate with each other by a basic P2P service with the service_name 'P2P_cd'. 4. UEP_b:generator&root can communicate with UEP_h:consumer&leaf, UEP_i:consumer&leaf and UEP_j:consumer&leaf by a basic RMP service with the service_name 'RMP_bhij'. But UEP_h:consumer&leaf, UEP_i:consumer&leaf and UEP_j:consumer&leaf can not communicate with each other. 5. UEP_g:participant can access the external internet through a P2Net basic service with the service_name 'P2Net_g'. +--------+ |Internet+----P2Net_g +--------+ | | +--+--+ |UEP_g| +--+--+ | +-----+ +-----+ +-----+ | +-----+ |UEP_a+---MP2MP_abc---+UEP_c+---P2P_cd---+UEP_d+---MP2MP_defg---+UEP_f| +-----+ | +-----+ +-----+ | +-----+ | | +--+--+ +--+--+ |UEP_b| |UEP_e| +--+--+ +-----+ | | +----RMP_bhij----+ | | | | | | +-----+ +--+--+ +-----+ |UEP_h| |UEP_i| |UEP_j| +-----+ +-----+ +-----+ Data Model Impact ----------------- Each of the above entities has the following attributes. User-Centric NaaS service instance: # id - UUID of the User-Centric NaaS service instance. # name - the name of the User-Centric NaaS service instance that has good readability. # tenant_id - UUID of the tenant or subscriber who runs this User-Centric NaaS service instance. # service_graph_id - UUID of the service graph this User-Centric NaaS service instance belongs to. # service_name - string, this name is used to associate multiple service instances in order to achieve one P2Net, P2P, MP2MP or RMP basic service. # list of UEP - A list of UEP UUIDs within in this User-Centric NaaS service instance. The UEPs have the same NaaS service requirements, can be associated to the same one service_contract within a service instance. # service_type - enum, service type of the User-Centric NaaS service instance. The service type may be P2Net (Point to Internet), P2P (Point to Point), MP2MP (Multipoint to Multipoint) and RMP (Rooted Multipoint). # service_contract - UUID of the service contract which customizes the requirements of this User-Centric NaaS service. UEP: # id - UUID of the UEP involved in this User-Centric NaaS service. # name - string, the name of the UEP that has good readability. # tenant_id - UUID of the tenant or subscriber who runs this User-Centric NaaS service instance. # UEP_service_role - enum, the UEP service role in this User-Centric NaaS service instance. Two types, Root or Leaf. Within the same User-Centric NaaS service instance, Root UEPs can communicate with each other and Root UEP can communicate with Leaf UEP. Leaf UEPs cannot communicate with each other. # UEP_traffic_role - enum, the UEP traffic role in this User-Centric NaaS service instance. Three types, Generator, Consumer and Participant. UEP with Generator type is one-way data source. UEP with Consumer type is one-way data sink. UEP with Participant is two-way symmetric data source/sink. # composite_UEP_address - The container of a list of UEP_address UUIDs for the composite address information of a UEP which has multiple addresses in a multilayer network. Composite_UEP_address: # id - UUID of the composite UPE address involved in this User-Centric NaaS service. # name - string, the name of the composite UEP address that has good readability. # tenant_id - UUID of the tenant or subscriber who runs this User-Centric NaaS service instance. # list of UEP_address - A list of UEP_address UUIDs for the composite address information of a UEP. UEP_address: # id - UUID of the UEP address for the UEP. # name - string, the name of the UEP address that has good readability. # tenant_id - UUID of the tenant or subscriber who runs this User-Centric NaaS service instance. # UEP_address_type - enum, type of the address for the UPE, such as location, IP address, MAC address, Vlan ID. # UEP_address_value - corresponding parameter of the address specified by the address type. Service_contract: # id - UUID of the service contract in this User-Centric NaaS service. # name - string, the name of service contract that has good readability. # service_level - A list of service level UUIDS, this is used for the SLA parameters of this User-Centric NaaS service instance. # servcie_schedule - UUID of the service schedule, this is used for the lifecycle of this User-Centric NaaS service instance. # bandwidth_profile - A list of bandwidth profile UUIDS, this is used for the committed bandwidth required for the User-Centric NaaS service instance. # leased_type - enum, this is used for the committed leased type, namely service layer, which indicates the service frame (or packet) definition used for bandwidth profiles, e.g. Layer 1, Layer 2 and Layer 3. # value_added_service - A list of value added service UUIDs. User-Centric NaaS service together provided by carries and service provides based on voice, data, images, SMS messages, and so on. Communication network technologies and Internet technologies are used to provide value-added services. Service_level: # id - UUID of the service level in this User-Centric NaaS service. # name - string, the name of service level that has good readability. # service_level_type - enum, this is the SLA parameter types of this User-Centric NaaS service instance. The SLA types may be availability, delay, delay_variation, loss_ratio and extension attributes. # servcie_level_value - double, the value or threshold of the SLA parameter specified by the service_level_type. Service_schedule: # id - UUID of the service schedule in this User-Centric NaaS service. # name - string, the name of service schedule that has good readability. # start_time - string, the start time of this User-Centric NaaS service instance. # start_interval - string, interval after the specified start time that it is acceptable for the service to start. This is for the flexibility for the start time of the User-Centric NaaS service instance. # period - string, this is the period for the repeated User-Centric NaaS service instance, which allows the service to recur. It may be daily, weekly or monthly. # duration - string, the duration of the User-Centric NaaS service instance. Bandwidth_profile: # id - UUID of the bandwidth profile in this User-Centric NaaS service. # name - string, the name of bandwidth profile that has good readability. # bandwidth_profile_type - enum, type of the bandwidth profile, such as CIR, CBS, EIR, EBS. # bandwidth_profile_value - double, corresponding parameter of the bandwidth profile according to the bandwidth profile type. Value_added_service: # id - UUID of the value added service in this User-Centric NaaS service. # name - string, the name of value added service that has good readability. # event - A list of event UUIDs within in this User-Centric NaaS service instance. This is used for the dynamic policy of the value added service in the User-Centric NaaS service instance, which include dynamic alarm and timer. # classifier - A list of classifier UUIDs within in this User-Centric NaaS service instance for static policy of the value added service in the User-Centric NaaS service instance, which is traffic classifier. # action - A list of action UUIDs within in this User-Centric NaaS service instance for actions and handling triggered by the event and classifier for the value added service in this User-Centric NaaS service instance. Event: # id - UUID of the event. # name - string, the name of event that has good readability. # event_type - enum, the types of event for the dynamic policy according User-Centric NaaS service instance requirements, such as delay alarm, delay variation alarm, loss ratio alarm, load ratio alarm and timer. # event_value - corresponding parameter of the event specified by the event type. Classifier: # id - UUID of the classifier. # name - string, the name of classifier that has good readability. # tenant_id - UUID of the tenant or subscriber who runs this User-Centric NaaS service instance. # classifier_type - enum, the types of the classifier for the static policy according to User-Centric NaaS service instance requirements, such as user ID, flow ID, URL and application type. # classifier_value - corresponding parameter of the classifier specified by the classifier type. Action: # id - UUID of the classifier. # name - string, the name of action that has good readability. # action_type - enum, the type of action that is triggered by the event (specified by event type and parameter) and matching classifier (specified by classifier type and parameter), such as permit, deny, logging, remarking, meter, CAR, TCP acceleration, video caching, firewall, DPI logging and service chaining. # action_value - corresponding parameter of the action specified by the action type. User-Experience Monitoring instance: # id - UUID of the monitoring instance. # name - string, the name of the User-Experience monitoring instance that has good readability. # tenant_id - UUID of the tenant or subscriber who owns this User-Experience monitoring instance. # service_graph_id - UUID of the service graph this User-Experience Monitoring instance belongs to. # source_id - the ID of the source UEP of this User-Experience monitoring instance, which is UUID. # destination_id - the ID of the destination UEP of this User-Experience monitoring instance, which is UUID. # test_type - enum, the type of the monitoring, such as periodic, once. # period_time - int, the time interval of period monitoring when the test type is periodic. # response_type - enum, the type of how the User-Experience monitoring results are reported, such as normal, only_alarm. For the normal response type, measurement results are reported at once or after each test period. For the only alarm response type, measurement results are reported only when the measured values exceed the alarm threshold. # Experience - A list of Experience UUIDs within in this User-Experience Monitoring instance. Experience: # id - UUID of the experience in the User-Experience monitoring instance. # name - string, the name of the experience that has good readability. # type - enum, the main type of User-Experience monitoring, such as reachability, load ratio, IP, TCP, UDP, HTTP. # subtype - enum, the subtype of the User-Experience monitoring, such as delay, delay variation, loss ratio. The type and subtype together specifies the type of User-Experience monitoring instance. The combination is illustrated in the following figure. +-------------------+--------------------------------------+ | | Subtype | | +--------+-------------------+---------+ | Experience type | | | | | | Delay | Delay_variation | Loss | +----+--------------+--------+-------------------+---------+ | | | | | | | | Reachability | X | X | X | | +--------------+--------+-------------------+---------+ | | | | | | | | Load_ratio | X | X | X | | +--------------+--------+-------------------+---------+ | | | | | | | | IP | V | V | V | |Type+--------------+--------+-------------------+---------+ | | | | | | | | TCP | V | V | X | | +--------------+--------+-------------------+---------+ | | | | | | | | UDP | V | V | X | | +--------------+--------+-------------------+---------+ | | | | | | | | HTTP | V | V | X | +----+--------------+--------+-------------------+---------+ REST API Impact --------------- The following new resources are being introduced: RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP = { 'delay_variation','loss_ratio']}, 'required': False, 'is_visible': True}, }, } Security Impact --------------- Standard Neutron tenant object ownership rules will apply. Notifications Impact -------------------- The format of the notification for the User-Experience Monitoring API: +--------------+------------+---------------------------------------------+ |key |Value |Notes | +--------------+------------+---------------------------------------------+ |id |Integer |The ID of User-Experience Monitoring instance| +--------------+------------+---------------------------------------------+ |test_type |String |The value should be "once" or "periodic" | +--------------+------------+---------------------------------------------+ |period_time |Integer |Time duration for two tests if test_type is | | | |set to "periodic" | +--------------+------------+---------------------------------------------+ |response_type |String |The value should be "normal" or "only alarm" | +--------------+------------+---------------------------------------------+ |notification | | | |_time |Integer |The time sending this notification | +--------------+------------+---------------------------------------------+ |reachability |Bool |True if reachable; False if not reachable | +--------------+------------+---------------------------------------------+ |load_ratio |float |The load ratio of committed bandwidth. | +--------------+------------+---------------------------------------------+ |delay(ms) |float |The packets delay from the source neutron | | | |port to the destination neutron port. | +--------------+------------+---------------------------------------------+ |delay_ | |The delay variation. | |variation(ms) |float | | +--------------+------------+---------------------------------------------+ |loss_ratio |float |The packet loss ratio. | +--------------+------------+---------------------------------------------+ Other End User Impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ This User-Centric NaaS API introduces the User-Centric NaaS Engine for compiling and mapping the User-Centric NaaS service instances and the User-Experience monitoring instances to the Neutron ports, subnets, network, bridges, routers or other underlying control and configuration API of virtual or physical network resources. This may have impact on the system performance. But this impact only happens during the service provisioning time. IPv6 Impact ----------- None Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None. Developer Impact ---------------- This API is a new extension API, and will not affect existing API. Community Impact ---------------- None. Alternatives ------------ None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Fengkai Li, lifengkai@huawei.com Chengyong Lin, linchengyong@huawei.com Wenxia Dong, dongwenxia@huawei.com Enhui Liu, liuenhui@huawei.com XiaoFeng Ji jixiaofeng@huawei.com Tao Xi, xitao@huawei.com Yuanshan Chen, chenyuanshan@huawei.com Chunxiu Jia, jiachunxiu@huawei.com Bo Cui, thucuibo@163.com Fan Xie, xiefan19910511@163.com Huan Yan, yanh14@mails.tsinghua.edu.cn Jiaqiang Liu, liujiaqiang12@mails.tsinghua.edu.cn Yong Li, liyong07@tsinghua.edu.cn Depeng Jin, jindp@mail.tsinghua.edu.cn Work Items ---------- User-Centric NaaS service API. User-Experience monitoring API. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Both, functional and, system tests will be added. Tempest Tests ------------- None. Functional Tests ---------------- None. API Tests --------- None. Documentation Impact ==================== User-Centric NaaS API will be added in the documentation. User-Experience Monitoring API will be added in the documentation. User Documentation ------------------ None. Developer Documentation ----------------------- None. References ========== None.

implements: blueprint e2e-wan-as-a-service

Change-Id: I62613f1359faf53f87dc350ebedead705b0692ba
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/64/155364/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================================ Open WAN As A Service (OpenWANaaS) ============================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/open-wan-as-a-service For the Cloud, DC, Enterprise applications or self-service subscribers, they need to collaborate with WAN to set up InterCloud/InterDC/InterEnterprise services. E2E (End-to-End) WAN services need to be able to be fast, easily customized or dynamically adjusted based on the requirements. From the application or self-service subscriber aspect, mostly the requirements are the communication requirements and SLA (Service Level Agreement) parameters between the two ends, without underlying network topology, nodes and links technical details and complex configurations. This blueprint proposes to add a new set of APIs and corresponding data models for the E2E WAN service customization and description. Moreover, the implementation and design are included in this blueprint. This extended APIs for Neutron makes E2E WAN service easier to be consumed as an E-business and enable the applications and customer for on-demand, self-service, automatic and instant service delivery and provisioning. Problem Description =================== Current there is no Neutron APIs for E2E WAN service customization. The requirements for InterCloud, InterDC and InterEnterprise applications and E2E WAN self-service users should be addressed. Thus with this extended API, the Neutron is capable of network control either within the datacenter or between datacenters. The requirements may include the following: 1. The applications or the self-service users can customize services at high level requirements in the form of service contracts, without low level networking techniques. 2. The applications or the self-service users can customize E2E WAN services by one-stop CRUD operations, which include the customization of lifecycle, connectivity, bandwidth, SLA, value-added service attributes. 3. The applications or the self-service users can customize E2E user-experience monitoring by one-stop CRUD operations, which include delay, jitter, and loss-ratio of IP/TCP/UDP/HTTP. 4. The applications or the self-service users can customize typical WAN services using designed service templates for ease of usage. 5. The customized service requirements should be mapped to various network resource interfaces. 6. The customized E2E WAN service may span over multiple domains, and thus network resources should be orchestrated over multiple domains. These requirements are crucial for the E2E WAN service customizations. It is valuable and highly needed to provide OpenWANaaS API to provide that. Proposed Change =============== This blueprint proposes three OpenWANaaS APIs (following item1-3) and infrastructure and architecture (following item 4): 1. User-centric(UC) WAN service API to address the requirements for the E2E WAN service customization. 2. User-experience (UE) monitoring API to address the requirement for the E2E user-experience monitoring to verify whether SLA parameters are met. 3. Inter-domain topology API for the inter-domain topology description/gathering and multi-domain WANaaS service segmentation/distribution. 4. A reference infrastructure and architecture to implement the propose APIs and the mapping of these WAN service requirements to various network resources interfaces. More specifically, the three OpenWANaaS APIs and their corresponding data models will be illustrated in the following parts in this blueprint. A new terminology is introduced in this blueprint. * UEP (User EndPoint): This is used for specifying in a user-centric WAN service instance how a UEP can communicate with other UEPs using service_type, and how a WAN service contract can be accessed by a UEP or a list of UEP which has the same WAN service requirements. For the E2E WAN services customization, WAN Service Contract is used for the communication requirements between the two ends. The WAN service contract is abstracted and network technology agnostic. Fort the SLA parameters, User-experience monitoring is used for the measurement of the SLA between two ends. The following figure shows the general idea of this blueprint. +-----------+ +-----------+ | +---------------------------+ | | | WAN Service Contract/ | | | UEP |User-experience monitoring | UEP | | +---------------------------+ | +-----------+ +-----------+ Besides UEP, the following term is used by the data models in this blueprint: * UC WAN Service Instance: This is used for specifying in a UC WAN service instance how a UEP can communicate with other UEPs using service type, and how a WAN service contract can be accessed by a UEP or a list of UEPs which has the same WAN service requirements. * Service type: This is used for the UC WAN service type including P2Net (Point to Internet), P2P (Point to Point), MP2MP (Multipoint to Multipoint) and RMP (Rooted Multipoint). * Service contract: This is used for the aggregation of the WAN service requirements including servicel_level, service_schedule, bandwidth_profile,leased_type and value_added_service. * UEP service role: This is used for the UEP service role when the service type is Root or Leaf. Root: UEP connected to root UNI in all service type; Leaf: UEP connected to leaf UNI in RMP service type. The Roots can communicate with each other. The Roots can communicate with the Leaves. The Leaves cannot communicate with each other. * UEP traffic role: This is used for the UEP role in the traffic direction including Generator (one-way data source), Consumer (one-way data sink) and Participant (two-way symmetric data source/sink). * UEP address: This is used for the address information of UEP. * Service level: This is used for describing the SLA requirement including availability, delay, delay_variation, and loss_ratio. * Service schedule: This is used for describing the service lifecycle requirement including start_time, start_interval, period, duration. * Bandwidth profile: This is used for the committed bandwidth requirement. * Leased type: This is used for the committed leased type, namely service layer, which indicates the service frame (or packet) definition used for bandwidth profiles. * Event: This is used for describing the events that triggers the associated actions, such as delay_alarm, delay_variation_alarm, loss_ratio _alarm, load_ratio_alarm and timer. * Classifier: This is used for describing the traffic classifiers for the associated actions, such as user_id, flow_id, url or app_type. * Action: This is used for describing the particular traffic handling triggered by the associated events on the traffic characterized by the associated classifiers. * Value added service: This is used for the association of events, classifiers and actions for describing the value-added service requirement. * UE monitor instance: This is the instance for user experience monitor service instance. * Experience: This is used for the user experience monitor types customization and description. * Inter-domain topology instance: This is the instance for inter-domain topology description and gathering for one specific domain. UEP access the network through the user internet interface (UNI) in one domain. UNI is a demarcation point between the responsibility of the service provider and the responsibility of the subscriber. One domain connects another domain via external network to network interface (ENNI). ENNI is an interface that specifies signaling and management functions between two networks. * UNI to ENNI path: This is the path between UNI and ENNI within one domain. * UNI: UEP access network through this interface. * ENNI to ENNI path: This is the path between ENNI and ENNI either within the same domain or different domains. For the inter-domain topology is illustrated in the following figure. +--------------+ +----+ +----+ +---+ENNI| |ENNI+---+ | +----+ Domain 3 +----+ | | +--------------+ | | | +--+--+ +---+--+ | ENNI| | ENNI | +---+-----+----+ +---+------+----+ | +----+ +----+ | | Domain 1 |ENNI+------+ENNI| Domain 2 | | +----+ +----+ | +----+---+-----+ +-----+---+-----+ |UNI| |UNI| +-+-+ +-+-+ | | +---+----+ +----+---+ | | | | | UEP | | UEP | | | | | +--------+ +--------+ Each of the above terms has the following attributes. UC WAN service instance: # id - UUID of the UC WAN service instance. # name  string, the name of the UC WAN service instance that has good readability. # tenant_id  UUID of the tenant or subscriber who runs this UC WAN service. # UEP  A list of UEPs UUIDs within in this UC WAN service instance. # servcie_type  enum, service type of the UC WAN service instance. The service type may be P2Net (Point to Internet), P2P (Point to Point), MP2MP (Multipoint to Multipoint) and RMP (Rooted Multipoint). # service_contract  UUID of the service contract for the customized requirements of this UC WAN service. UEP # id  UUID of the UEP involved in this UC WAN service. # name - string, the name of the UEP that has good readability. # UEP_service_role  The UEP service role in this UC WAN service instance. Two types, Root or Leaf. Within the same UC WAN service instance, Root UEPs can communicate with each other and Root UEP can communicate with Leaf UEP. Leaf UEPs cannot communicate with each other. # UEP_traffic_role  The UEP traffic role in this UC WAN service instance. Three types, Generator, Consumer and Participant. UEP with Generator type is one-way data source. UEP with Consumer type is one-way data sink. UEP with Participant is two-way symmetric data source/sink. # UEP_address  A list of UEP address UUIDs for the address information of this specified UEP. UEP address # id  UUID of the UEP address for the UEP. # name  string, the name of the UEP address that has good readability. # UEP_address_type  enum, type of the address for the UPE, such as location, IP address, MAC address, Vlan ID. # UEP_address_value  corresponding parameter of the address specified by the address type. Service contract: # id - UUID of the service contract in this UC WAN service. # name - string, the name of service contract that has good readability. # service_level  A list of service level UUIDS, this is for the SLA parameters of this UC WAN service instance. # servcie_schedule  UUID of the service schedule, this is for the lifecycle of this UC WAN service instance. # bandwidth_profile  A list of bandwidth profile UUIDS,this is for the committed bandwidth required for the UC WAN service instance. # leased_type  enum, this is for the service frame definition used for bandwidth profile of the UC WAN service, e.g. Layer 1, Layer 2 and Layer 3. # value_added_service  A list of value added service UUIDs. UC WAN service together provided by carries and service provides based on voice, data, images, SMS messages, and so on. Communication network technologies and Internet technologies are used to provide value-added services. Service level: # id - UUID of the service level in this UC WAN service. # name - string, the name of service level that has good readability. # service_level_type  enum, this s the SLA parameter types of this UC WAN service instance. The SLA types may be availability, delay, delay_variation, loss_ratio and extension attributes. # servcie_level_value  double, the value or threshold of the SLA parameter specified by the service_level_type. Service schedule: # id - UUID of the service schedule in this UC WAN service. # name - string, the name of service schedule that has good readability. # start_time  string, the start time of this UC WAN service instance. # start_interval  string, this is for the flexibility for the start time of the UC WAN service instance, interval after the specified start time that it is acceptable for the service to start. # period  string, this is the period for the repeated UC WAN service instance, which allows the service to recur. It may be daily, weekly or monthly. # duration  string, the duration of the UC WAN service instance. Bandwidth profile: # id - UUID of the bandwidth profile in this UC WAN service. # name - string, the name of bandwidth profile that has good readability. # bandwidth_profile_type  enum, type of the bandwidth profile, such as CIR, CBS, EIR, EBS. # bandwidth_profile_value  double, corresponding parameter of the bandwidth profile specified by the bandwidth profile type. Value added service: # id - UUID of the value added service in this UC WAN service. # name - string, the name of value added service that has good readability. # event  A list of event UUIDs within in this UC WAN service instance for the dynamic policy for the value added service in the UC WAN service instance, which include dynamic alarm and timer. # classifier  A list of classifier UUIDs within in this UC WAN service instance for static policy for the value added service in the UC WAN service instance, which is traffic classifier. # action  A list of action UUIDs within in this UC WAN service instance for actions and handlings triggered by the event and classifier for the value added service in this UC WAN service instance. Event: # id - UUID of the event. # name - string, the name of event that has good readability. # event_type  enum, the types of event for the dynamic policy according to UC WAN service instance requirements, such as delay alarm, delay variation alarm, loss ratio alarm, load ratio alarm and timer. # event_value  corresponding parameter of the event specified by the event type. Classifier: # id - UUID of the classifier. # name - string, the name of classifier that has good readability. # classifier_type  enum, the types of the classifier for the static policy according to UC WAN service instance requirements, such as user ID, flow ID, URL, application type. # classifier_value  corresponding parameter of the classifier specified by the classifier type. Action: # id - UUID of the classifier. # name - string, the name of action that has good readability. # action_type  enum, the type of action that is triggered by the event (specified by event type and parameter) and matching classifier (specified by classifier type and parameter), such as permit, deny, logging, remarking, meter, CAR, TCP acceleration, video caching, firewall, DPI logging, service chaining. # action_value  corresponding parameter of the action specified by the action type. UE monitor instance: # id - UUID of the monitor instance. # name  string, the name of the UE monitor instance that has good readability. # tenant_id UUID of the tenant or subscriber who runs this UE monitor instance. # source_id  the ID of the source UEP for this UE monitor instance, which is UUID. # destination_id  the ID of the destination UEP for this UE monitor instance, which is UUID. # test_type  enum, the type of the monitoring, periodic, once. # period_time  int, the monitoring period time when the test type is periodic. # response_type  enum, the type how the UE monitor result is reported, normal or only_alarm. For the normal response type, measurement results are reported at once or after each test period. For the only alarm response type, measurement results are reported only when the measured values exceed the alarm threshold. # experience_type  A list of experience UUIDs within in this UE monitor instance. Experience: # id - UUID of the experience in the UE monitor instance. # name - string, the name of the experience that has good readability. # type  enum, the main type of UE monitor, such as reachability, load ratio, IP, TCP, UDP, http. # subtype  enum, the subtype of the UE monitor, such as delay, delay variation, loss. The type and subtype together specifies the type of UE monitoring instance. The combination is illustrated in the following figure. +-------------------+--------------------------------------+ | | Subtype | | +--------+-------------------+---------+ | Experience type | | | | | | Delay | Delay_variation | Loss | +----+--------------+--------+-------------------+---------+ | | | | | | | | Reachability | X | X | X | | +--------------+--------+-------------------+---------+ | | | | | | | | Load_ratio | X | X | X | | +--------------+--------+-------------------+---------+ | | | | | | | | IP | V | V | V | |Type+--------------+--------+-------------------+---------+ | | | | | | | | TCP | V | V | X | | +--------------+--------+-------------------+---------+ | | | | | | | | UDP | V | V | X | | +--------------+--------+-------------------+---------+ | | | | | | | | HTTP | V | V | X | +----+--------------+--------+-------------------+---------+ Inter-domain topology instance: # id - UUID of the inter-domain topology instance. # name - string, the name of the inter-domain topology instance that has good readability. # domain_id  UUID of the domain reporting this inter-domain topology instance. # domain_name  string, the name of the domain that has good readability. # controller_info  string, the controller information for the specified domain. # uni_enni_path_list  A list of UNI to ENNI path UUIDs within one domain. # enni_enni_path_list  A list of ENNI to ENNI path UUIDs either within the same domain or different domains. UNI to ENNI path: # id  UUID of the UNI to ENNI path # name  string, the name of this path that has good readability. # path_type  enum, the type of this path, i.e. physical link, virtual link (e.g. TE link), or routing path (e.g. best-effort path). # path_direction  enum, the direction of this path, i.e. forward_direction (from UNI to ENNI), backward_direction (from ENNI to UNI), bidirectional (both forward_direction and backward_direction). # path_cost  string, the cost value of this path. # path_bandwidth  string, the bandwidth of the path when the path type is physical link or virtual link. # oper_status  enum, running status of this path, such as up and down. # uni  UUID of UNI in this UNI to ENNI path. This is the left end of the path. # enni_node_id  UUID of the node that the ENNI belongs to. This is the right end of the path. # enni_tp_id  UUID of the termination point of the right end of the path. UNI: # id  UUID of the UNI. # name  string, the name of the UNI that has good readability. # uni_node_id  UUID of the node that the UNI belongs to. This is the left end of the path. # uni_tp_id  UUID of the termination point for the left end of the path. # uep_address_list  A list of UEP address UUIDs. This is the list of user endpoint address information. The user endpoints access the network via this UNI.This list may contain one or multiple UPE addresses. ENNI to ENNI path: # id  UUID of the ENNI to ENNI path. # name  string, the name of this path that has good readability. # path_type  enum, the type of this path, i.e. physical link, virtual link (e.g. TE link), or routing path (e.g. best-effort path). # path_direction  enum, the direction of this path, i.e. forward_direction (from srcNode to the dstNode), backward_direction (from dstNode to the srcNode), bidirectional (both forward_direction and backward_direction). # path_cost  string, the bandwidth of the path when the path type is physical link or virtual link. # path_bandwidth  string, the bandwidth of the path when the path type is physical link or virtual link. # oper_status  enum, running status of this path. # src_domain_id  UUID that uniquely identifies the domain that the ENNI belongs to. This ENNI is the left end of the path. # src_node_id  UUID of the node that the ENNI belongs to. This ENNI is the left end of the path. # src_tp_id  UUID of the termination point of the left end of the path. # dst_domain_id  UUID that uniquely identifies the domain that the ENNI belongs to. This ENNI is the right end of the path. # dst_node_id  UUID of the node that the ENNI belongs to. This ENNI is the right end of the path. # dst_tp_id  UUID of the termination point of the right end of the path. Impact --------------- Standard Neutron tenant object ownership rules will apply. Notifications Impact -------------------- The format of the notification for the UE monitor: +--------------+------------+--------------------------------------------------------+ |key |Value |Notes | +--------------+------------+--------------------------------------------------------+ |id |Integer |VNPM ID | +--------------+------------+--------------------------------------------------------+ |test_type |String |The value should be "once" or "periodic" | +--------------+------------+--------------------------------------------------------+ |period_time |Integer |Time duration for two tests if test_type is set to | | | |"periodic" | +--------------+------------+--------------------------------------------------------+ |response_type |String |The value should be "normal" or "only alarm" | +--------------+------------+--------------------------------------------------------+ |notification | | | |_time |Integer |The time sending this notification | +--------------+------------+--------------------------------------------------------+ |reachability |Bool |True if reachable; False if not reachable | +--------------+------------+--------------------------------------------------------+ |delay(ms) |float |The packets delay from the source neutron port to the | | | |destination neutron port | +--------------+------------+--------------------------------------------------------+ |jitter(ms) |float |The delay jitter | +--------------+------------+--------------------------------------------------------+ |loss |float |packets loss ratio | +--------------+------------+--------------------------------------------------------+ Other End User Impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ This openWANaaS API introduces the mapping engine translating the UC WAN service and the UE monitoring information model to the Neutron or controllers network resource model. This may have impact on the system performance. But this is only for the service customization time and there will be no impact after the service is deployed or provisioned. IPv6 Impact ----------- None Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None. Developer Impact ---------------- This API is a new extension API, and will not affect existing API. Community Impact ---------------- None. Alternatives ------------ None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary Assignee: Fengkai Li lifengkai@huawei.com Chengyong Lin linchengyong@huawei.com Wenxia Dong dongwenxia@huawei.com Bo Cui thucuibo@163.com Fan Xie xiefan19910511@163.com Huan Yan yanh14@mails.tsinghua.edu.cn Other Contributors: Enhui Liu liuenhui@huawei.com Jiaqiang Liu liujiaqiang12@mails,tsinghua.cn Yong Li liyong07@tsinghua.edu.cn Depeng Jin jindp@mail.tsinghua.edu.cn Work Items ---------- UC WAN service API. UE monitor API. Inter-domain topology API. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Both, functional and, system tests will be added. Tempest Tests ------------- None Functional Tests ---------------- None API Tests --------- None Documentation Impact ==================== OpenWANaaS API will be added in the documentation. User Documentation ------------------ None Developer Documentation ----------------------- None References ========== None

subject: Add port timestamp
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-04 04:03:45.000000000', 'files': ['specs/kilo/add-port-timestamp.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs/commit/2e3a287ec83e946b86b4ff2278d5c946116809e5', 'message': 'Add port timestamp

Blueprint: add-port-timestamp
APIImpact

Change-Id: I90e635930419ad644d671ec8d23a83a4eaf9873d
'}]
commit_message:
Add port timestamp

Blueprint: add-port-timestamp
APIImpact

Change-Id: I90e635930419ad644d671ec8d23a83a4eaf9873d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/67/152767/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== add-port-timestamp ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/add-port-timestamp It is worth adding timestamp fields including create_at, update_at in the table of port in neutron, so users can monitor port change conveniently, for example portal or management center would like to query the ports that have changed or refreshed during the latest 5 seconds in a large scale application. If not, it's time-consuming and inefficient. Problem Description =================== Currently we don't have timestamp fields associated with port in neutron, so there's no way that we query ports based on the time they are operated. End users may be interested in ports operated in a specific period for monitoring or statistics purpose but this requirement can not be fulfilled currently. Proposed Change =============== We propose to add create_at and update_at fields to port model. Both the default value of create_at and update_at are set to timeutils.utcnow(). Also onupdate trigger is set to update_at to refresh update_at to timeutils.utcnow() when a port is updated. All the timestamp field operation can be finished in the database side, so there is no extra work needed in the plugin side. Based on these fields, change_since filter is introduced when retrieving ports. It accepts a timestamp and neutron will return ports whose update_at fields are later than this timestamp. Data Model Impact ----------------- Two new attributes added to ports: +----------------+----------+--------------------+----------+------+---------------------------+ | Attribute name | Type | Default Value | Required | CRUD | Description | +----------------+----------+--------------------+----------+------+---------------------------+ | created_at | DateTime | timeutils.utcnow() | Y | | Timestamp port is created | | updated_at | DateTime | timeutils.utcnow() | Y | | Timestamp port is updated | +----------------+----------+--------------------+----------+------+---------------------------+ Both created_at and updated_at are maintained by neutron and users do not care about them, so CRUD are all empty. REST API Impact --------------- New added field create_at and updated_at are maintained by neutron so they will not bring API impact. Ports list API will accept new query string parameter change_since. Users can pass time to the list API url to retrieve ports operated since a specific time. Security Impact --------------- None Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- Python neutron client may add help to inform users this new filter. Python neutron client support dynamic assigning search fields so it is easy for it to support this new filter. Performance Impact ------------------ Performance of syncing port status with other systems, like a monitor system or a user interface, can be improved. Instead of retrieving all the ports in every syncing period to update port status, these systems can just retrieve ports updated during the syncing interval using the new change_since filter. IPv6 Impact ----------- None Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None Developer Impact ---------------- None Community Impact ---------------- This change will bring facility to monitor neutron port resources. Actually most projects in OpenStack like nova, cinder have timestamp fields to track the operation time of resources. Alternatives ------------ None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: caizhiyuan1@huawei.com Other contributors: TBD Work Items ---------- * Update database schema * Add API filter * Add related test Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- None Functional Tests ---------------- * Test if create_at and update_at can be correctly initiated. * Test if update_at can be correctly written when port updated. * Test if change_since filter can be correctly applied. API Tests --------- Test if the new filter can be correctly parsed and validated. Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ Update neutron API reference Developer Documentation ----------------------- None References ========== None

commit_message:
Add availability_zone support

By adding the availability_zone attribute to agents, networks and
routers, users will be able to specify where network services run.

APIImpact
DocImpact

Co-Authored-By: IWAMOTO Toshihiro <iwamoto@valinux.co.jp>

Change-Id: Ib8ed2e7fd1a518f9199a9d3852d62a9ec604e276
Implements: blueprint add-availability-zone
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/12/169612/21 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================= Add availability zones for agents ================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/add-availability-zone Implement availability zones for the DHCP and L3 agents. Just like Nova and Cinder, this allows users to specify where the network services run, giving better fault isolation. Problem Description =================== Nova and Cinder have availability zones today. Cloud administrators can assign availability zones to physical nodes based on geographical locations etc. By properly choosing from the provided availability zones, users can minimize their chance of service failures. But, as Neutron doesn't have availability zones, there's no way to put network services under the same availability zone as a VM instance or a VM volume. What happens with Neutron is completely by chance today. A user cannot limit network traffic within an availability zone, risking higher probability of network failure. Also, network traffic can go through long paths between availability zones. DVR and L3 HA can mitigate these issues somewhat, but they don't entirely solve the problem. Proposed Change =============== The availability_zone attribute is added to the Network, Router and Agent DB models. The corresponding API resources will see the availability_zone attribute, too. The new attribute will be used by agent schedulers: * Router.availability_zone is used to schedule non-DVR routers and dvr_snat routers. * Network.availability_zone is used to schedule DHCP agents. The new config options availability_zone and default_availability_zone are added. In addition to the above, a new API that lists availability zones will be added. Data Model Impact ----------------- As noted above, the availability_zone attribute is added to the Network and Router DB models. A migration script will be provided. REST API Impact --------------- The following new attribute is added to the network and router API resources: .. csv-table:: New attribute :header: Attribute Name,Type,Access,Default Value,Validation Conversion,Description availability_zone,string,"RW(post only), all","neutron",string,human-readable name There will be the new availability-zone API resource. An example of a JSON response: :: { "availability_zones": [ { "zoneState": {"available": true}, "zoneName": "neutron" }] } Security Impact --------------- None. Notifications Impact -------------------- None. Other End User Impact --------------------- Performance Impact ------------------ This will reduce intra-datacenter traffic and improve performance. IPv6 Impact ----------- None. This proposal is protocol agnostic. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- To make use of this feature, deployers need to set availability_zone in the neutron.conf config files. Developer Impact ---------------- Community Impact ---------------- Alternatives ------------ None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: iwamoto Work Items ---------- * Add availability_zone to the DB models * Make agents report their availability_zone settings * Add the availability_zone attribute to the API resources * Add the availability-zone API resource so that AZs can be listed * (Validate REST API availability_zone parameters) * Add AvailabilityZoneFilter based on existing implementations * Modify the router and DHCP agent schedulers to be AZ aware * XXX dvrsched Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- Functional Tests ---------------- API Tests --------- Tests for the new attribute and the new API resource will be added. Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ The new config options will be documented. Developer Documentation ----------------------- None. References ========== * Nova availability zone * Cinder availability zone

commit_message:
Remove old REST to ZOOM from devstack

Now that the cluster REST API is ready to be consumed, remove the
option to use the legacy MidoNet API to go to ZOOM.

Change-Id: Ia12e4c2223057aba5ca3aa6b42b98cd9bec2e401
Implements: MNP-159
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-midonet refs/changes/13/194613/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # This flag indicates to the MidoNet agent to use ZOOM instead of DataClient ZK # backend of MidoNet NSDB. MIDONET_USE_ZOOM=${MIDONET_USE_ZOOM:-False} if [[ "$MIDONET_USE_ZOOM" == "True" ]]; then MIDONET_SERVICE_API_PORT=$MIDONET_CLUSTER_API_PORT else MIDONET_SERVICE_API_PORT=$MIDONET_API_PORT fi
deleted_lines: # Currently in the transition phase of MidoNet from v1 to v2, there are several # ways to access the API. Instead of trying to figure out which port to use in # the code, just let the user choose by setting the port to # MIDONET_SERVICE_API_PORT. The port number must be either MIDONET_API_PORT # or MIDONET_CLUSTER_API_PORT. MIDONET_SERVICE_API_PORT=${MIDONET_SERVICE_API_PORT:-$MIDONET_API_PORT}# This flag indicates to the MidoNet agent to use ZOOM instead of DataClient ZK # backend of MidoNet NSDB. MIDONET_USE_ZOOM=${MIDONET_USE_ZOOM:-False}

commit_message:
API: Get a subset of fields from Ports and Chassis

Since this feature is enabled for nodes we should make other resources
to consistently support this feature, so this patch allows users
to specify a list of fields that will be returned when GET'ing a port
or chassis (or a collection of those)

A small refactor was done as part of the test_port.py and test_chassis.py
to make the import names consistent across the tests modules for nodes,
ports and chassis resources.

APIImpact
Closes-Bug: #1466495

commit_message:
move replication code to ReplicatedObjectController

Moving _connect_put_node, send_file, _transfer_data and _store_object
methods to ReplicatedObjectController. Each one of these methods are
specific to replication policy.  EC policy implements their own
version of them.

Of these four methods, only _store_object and _connect_put_node are
required to be implemented by the policy specific Object Controllers.

Change-Id: Ifc72461b77dbfdaae9d63417f1286e8b5da3ca4e
Signed-off-by: Thiago da Silva <thiago@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/26/182826/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
